settings.name: token
settings.label: API Token
settings.description: Your Airtable API token.

settings.name: base_id
settings.label: Base ID
settings.description: The Airtable base ID. Airtable base IDs begin with "app".

settings.name: records_url
settings.label: Records URL
settings.description: Airtable Records URL, defaults to https://api.airtable.com/v0

description: Apprise allows you to send a notification to almost all of the most popular notification services available to us today such as: Telegram, Discord, Slack, Amazon SNS, Gotify, etc
label: Apprise
name: target-apprise

settings.name: uris
settings.label: URIs
settings.description: Array of apprise URIs

settings.name: athena_database
settings.label: Athena Database
settings.description: The name of the Athena database to connect to.

settings.name: aws_region
settings.label: AWS Region
settings.description: The AWS region to use i.e. us-east-2.

settings.name: aws_access_key_id
settings.label: AWS S3 Access Key ID
settings.description: S3 Access Key Id. If not provided, aws_profile or AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_session_token
settings.label: AWS S3 Session Token
settings.description: Optional - S3 AWS STS token for temporary credentials. If not provided, AWS_SESSION_TOKEN environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_profile
settings.label: AWS profile name
settings.description: Optional - AWS profile name for profile based authentication. If not provided, AWS_PROFILE environment variable will be used.

settings.name: s3_bucket
settings.label: Bucket
settings.description: AWS S3 bucket name

settings.name: s3_key_prefix
settings.label: S3 Key Prefix
settings.description: A static prefix before the generated S3 key names. Using prefixes you can upload files into specific directories in the S3 bucket. Default(None)

settings.name: s3_staging_dir
settings.label: S3 Staging Directory
settings.description: S3 location to stage files. Example - s3://YOUR_S3_BUCKET/path/to/

settings.name: delimiter
settings.label: Delimiter
settings.description: (Default - ',') A one-character string used to separate fields.

settings.name: quotechar
settings.label: Quote Character
settings.description: (Default - '"') A one-character string used to quote fields containing special characters, such as the delimiter or quotechar, or which contain new-line characters.

settings.name: add_record_metadata
settings.label: Add Record Metadata
settings.description: (Default - False) Metadata columns add extra row level information about data ingestions, (i.e. when was the row read in source, when was inserted or deleted in snowflake etc.) Metadata columns are creating automatically by adding extra columns to the tables with a column prefix _sdc_. The column names are following the stitch naming conventions documented at https://www.stitchdata.com/docs/data-structure/integration-schemas#sdc-columns. Enabling metadata columns will flag the deleted rows by setting the _sdc_deleted_at metadata column. Without the add_record_metadata option the deleted rows from singer taps will not be recongisable in Snowflake.

settings.name: encryption_type
settings.label: Encryption Type
settings.description: (Default - 'none') The type of encryption to use. Current supported options are - 'none' and 'KMS'.

settings.name: encryption_key
settings.label: Encryption Key
settings.description: A reference to the encryption key to use for data encryption. For KMS encryption, this should be the name of the KMS encryption key ID (e.g. '1234abcd-1234-1234-1234-1234abcd1234'). This field is ignored if 'encryption_type' is none or blank.

settings.name: compression
settings.label: Compression
settings.description: The type of compression to apply before uploading. Supported options are none (default) and gzip. For gzipped files, the file extension will automatically be changed to .csv.gz for all files.

settings.name: naming_convention
settings.label: Naming Convention
settings.description: (Default - None) Custom naming convention of the s3 key. Replaces tokens date, stream, and timestamp with the appropriate values. Supports "folders" in s3 keys e.g. folder/folder2/{stream}/export_date={date}/{timestamp}.csv. Honors the s3_key_prefix, if set, by prepending the "filename". E.g. naming_convention = folder1/my_file.csv and s3_key_prefix = prefix_ results in folder1/prefix_my_file.csv

settings.name: temp_dir
settings.label: Temp Directory
settings.description: (Default - platform-dependent) Directory of temporary CSV files with RECORD messages.

settings.name: object_format
settings.label: Object Format
settings.description: (Default - jsonl) The format to write the S3 in - jsonl or csv

settings.name: flatten_records
settings.label: Flattten Records
settings.description: Whether to flatten nested import data before loading it to Athena.

settings.name: project_id
settings.description: BigQuery project
settings.label: Project Id

settings.name: dataset_id
settings.description: BigQuery dataset
settings.label: Dataset Id

settings.name: location
settings.description: Dataset location
settings.label: Location

settings.name: credentials_path
settings.description: This is not a real setting, so it should not appear in the `config.json` JSON schema. The taret will read the `GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS` environment variable which should be a fully qualified path to `client_secrets.json` for your service account.

settings.name: validate_records
settings.description: Validate records
settings.label: Validate Records

settings.name: add_metadata_columns
settings.description: Add `_time_extracted` and `_time_loaded` metadata columns
settings.label: Add Metadata Columns

settings.name: replication_method
settings.description: Replication method, `append` or `truncate`
settings.label: Replication Method

settings.name: table_prefix
settings.description: Add prefix to table name
settings.label: Table Prefix

settings.name: table_suffix
settings.description: Add suffix to table name
settings.label: Table Suffix

settings.name: max_cache
settings.description: Maximum cache size in MB
settings.label: Max Cache

settings.name: merge_state_messages
settings.description: Whether to merge multiple state messages from the tap into the state file or uses the last state message as the state file.
settings.label: Merge State Messages

settings.name: table_config
settings.description: A path to a file containing the definition of partitioning and clustering.
settings.label: Table Config

settings.name: dataset_id
settings.description: BigQuery dataset
settings.label: Dataset Id

settings.name: project_id
settings.description: BigQuery project
settings.label: Project Id

settings.name: location
settings.description: Region where BigQuery stores your dataset
settings.label: Location

settings.name: batch_size_rows
settings.description: Maximum number of rows in each batch. At the end of each batch, the rows in the batch are loaded into BigQuery.
settings.label: Batch Size Rows

settings.name: flush_all_streams
settings.description: Flush and load every stream into BigQuery when one batch is full. Warning - This may trigger transfer of data with low number of records, and may cause performance problems.
settings.label: Flush All Streams

settings.name: parallelism
settings.description: The number of threads used to flush tables. 0 will create a thread for each stream, up to parallelism_max. -1 will create a thread for each CPU core. Any other positive number will create that number of threads, up to parallelism_max.
settings.label: Parallelism

settings.name: max_parallelism
settings.description: Max number of parallel threads to use when flushing tables.
settings.label: Max Parallelism

settings.name: default_target_schema
settings.description: Name of the schema where the tables will be created. If schema_mapping is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is loaded into this schema.
settings.label: Default Target Schema

settings.name: default_target_schema_select_permission
settings.description: Grant USAGE privilege on newly created schemas and grant SELECT privilege on newly created
settings.label: Default Target Schema Select Permission

settings.name: schema_mapping
settings.description: (Experimental) Useful if you want to load multiple streams from one tap to multiple BigQuery schemas. If the tap sends the stream_id in <schema_name>-<table_name> format then this option overwrites the default_target_schema value. Note, that using schema_mapping you can overwrite the default_target_schema_select_permission value to grant SELECT permissions to different groups per schemas or optionally you can create indices automatically for the replicated tables.
settings.label: Schema Mapping

settings.name: add_metadata_columns
settings.description: Metadata columns add extra row level information about data ingestions, (i.e. when was the row read in source, when was inserted or deleted in bigquery etc.) Metadata columns are creating automatically by adding extra columns to the tables with a column prefix _sdc_. The column names are following the stitch naming conventions documented at https://www.stitchdata.com/docs/data-structure/integration-schemas#sdc-columns. Enabling metadata columns will flag the deleted rows by setting the _sdc_deleted_at metadata column. Without the add_metadata_columns option the deleted rows from singer taps will not be recognisable in BigQuery.
settings.label: Add Metadata Columns

settings.name: hard_delete
settings.description: When hard_delete option is true then DELETE SQL commands will be performed in BigQuery to delete rows in tables. It's achieved by continuously checking the _sdc_deleted_at metadata column sent by the singer tap. Due to deleting rows requires metadata columns, hard_delete option automatically enables the add_metadata_columns option as well.
settings.label: Hard Delete

settings.name: data_flattening_max_level
settings.description: Object type RECORD items from taps can be loaded into VARIANT columns as JSON (default) or we can flatten the schema by creating columns automatically. When value is 0 (default) then flattening functionality is turned off.
settings.label: Data Flattening Max Level

settings.name: primary_key_required
settings.description: Log based and Incremental replications on tables with no Primary Key cause duplicates when merging UPDATE events. When set to true, stop loading data if no Primary Key is defined.
settings.label: Primary Key Required

settings.name: validate_records
settings.description: Validate every single record message to the corresponding JSON schema. This option is disabled by default and invalid RECORD messages will fail only at load time by BigQuery. Enabling this option will detect invalid records earlier but could cause performance degradation.
settings.label: Validate Records

settings.name: temp_schema
settings.description: Name of the schema where the temporary tables will be created. Will default to the same schema as the target tables.
settings.label: Temp Schema

name: csv
label: CSV
description: For loading data into [Comma Separated Values (CSV)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comma-separated_values) files

settings.name: destination_path
settings.description: Sets the destination path the CSV files are written to, relative to the project root. The directory needs to exist already, it will not be created automatically. To write CSV files to the project root, set an empty string (`""`).

settings.name: delimiter
settings.description: A one-character string used to separate fields. It defaults to a comma (,).

settings.name: quotechar
settings.description: A one-character string used to quote fields containing special characters, such as the delimiter or quotechar, or which contain new-line characters. It defaults to single quote (').

settings.name: destination_path
settings.description: Sets the destination path the CSV files are written to, relative to the project root. The directory needs to exist already, it will not be created automatically. To write CSV files to the project root, set an empty string (`""`).

settings.name: delimiter
settings.description: A one-character string used to separate fields. It defaults to a comma (,).

settings.name: quotechar
settings.description: A one-character string used to quote fields containing special characters, such as the delimiter or quotechar, or which contain new-line characters. It defaults to single quote (').

settings.name: spreadsheet_id
settings.label: Spreadsheet ID
settings.description: The unique identifier for a spreadsheet.

settings.name: destination_path
settings.description: Sets the destination path the JSONL files are written to, relative to the project root. The directory needs to exist already, it will not be created automatically. To write JSONL files to the project root, set an empty string (`""`).

settings.name: do_timestamp_file
settings.label: Include timestamp in file names
settings.description: Specifies if the files should get timestamped

settings.name: stream_name
settings.label: Stream Name
settings.description: The name of the Kinesis stream to write to.

settings.name: aws_access_key_id
settings.label: AWS S3 Access Key ID
settings.description: S3 Access Key Id. If not provided, aws_profile or AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_secret_access_key
settings.label: AWS S3 Secret Access Key
settings.description: S3 Secret Access Key. If not provided, aws_profile or AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID environment variable will be used.

settings.name: region
settings.label: AWS Region
settings.description: The AWS region to use i.e. us-east-2.

settings.name: is_firehose
settings.label: Is Firehouse
settings.description: (Default False) Whether to user a Firehouse client or not.

settings.name: record_chunks
settings.label: Record Chunks
settings.description: (Default - 10) The max number of records per chunk.

settings.name: data_chunks
settings.label: Data Chunks
settings.description: (Default - 1000) The max size of data per chunk.

settings.name: partition_key
settings.label: Partition Key
settings.description: (Default - `id`) The partition key to use when writing to Kinesis.

settings.name: disable_collection
settings.label: Disable Collection
settings.description: A boolean of whether to disable Singer anonymous tracking.

settings.name: logging_level
settings.label: Logging Level
settings.description: (Default - INFO) The log level. Can also be set using environment variables.

settings.name: destination_path
settings.label: Destination Path
settings.description: (Default - '.') The path to write files out to.

settings.name: compression_method
settings.label: Compression Method
settings.description: Compression methods have to be supported by Pyarrow, and currently the compression modes available are - snappy (recommended), zstd, brotli and gzip.

settings.name: streams_in_separate_folder
settings.label: Streams In Separate Folder
settings.description: (Default - False) The option to create each stream in a different folder, as these are expected to come in different schema.

settings.name: file_size
settings.label: File Size
settings.description: The number of rows to write per file. The default is to write to a single file.

variants.name: datamill-co
dependencies: `target-postgres` [requires](https://www.psycopg.org/docs/install.html#runtime-requirements) the [`libpq` library](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq.html) to be available on your system. If you've installed PostgreSQL, you should already have it, but you can also install it by itself using the [`libpq-dev` package](https://pkgs.org/download/libpq-dev) on Ubuntu/Debian or the [`libpq` Homebrew formula](https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/libpq) on macOS.

settings.name: postgres_sslmode
settings.description: Refer to the libpq docs for more information about SSL: https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq-connect.html#LIBPQ-PARAMKEYWORDS

settings.name: postgres_sslcert
settings.description: Only used if a SSL request w/ a client certificate is being made

settings.name: postgres_sslkey
settings.description: Only used if a SSL request w/ a client certificate is being made

settings.name: postgres_sslrootcert
settings.description: Used for authentication of a server SSL certificate

settings.name: postgres_sslcrl
settings.description: Used for authentication of a server SSL certificate

settings.name: invalid_records_detect
settings.description: Include `false` in your config to disable `target-postgres` from crashing on invalid records

settings.name: invalid_records_threshold
settings.description: Include a positive value `n` in your config to allow for `target-postgres` to encounter at most `n` invalid records per stream before giving up.

settings.name: disable_collection
settings.description: Include `true` in your config to disable Singer Usage Logging: https://github.com/datamill-co/target-postgres#usage-logging

settings.name: logging_level
settings.description: The level for logging. Set to `DEBUG` to get things like queries executed, timing of those queries, etc.

settings.name: persist_empty_tables
settings.description: Whether the Target should create tables which have no records present in Remote.

settings.name: max_batch_rows
settings.description: The maximum number of rows to buffer in memory before writing to the destination table in Postgres

settings.name: max_buffer_size
settings.description: The maximum number of bytes to buffer in memory before writing to the destination table in Postgres. Default: 100MB in bytes

settings.name: batch_detection_threshold
settings.description: How often, in rows received, to count the buffered rows and bytes to check if a flush is necessary. There's a slight performance penalty to checking the buffered records count or bytesize, so this controls how often this is polled in order to mitigate the penalty. This value is usually not necessary to set as the default is dynamically adjusted to check reasonably often.

settings.name: state_support
settings.description: Whether the Target should emit `STATE` messages to stdout for further consumption. In this mode, which is on by default, STATE messages are buffered in memory until all the records that occurred before them are flushed according to the batch flushing schedule the target is configured with.

settings.name: add_upsert_indexes
settings.description: Whether the Target should create column indexes on the important columns used during data loading. These indexes will make data loading slightly slower but the deduplication phase much faster. Defaults to on for better baseline performance.

settings.name: before_run_sql
settings.description: Raw SQL statement(s) to execute as soon as the connection to Postgres is opened by the target. Useful for setup like `SET ROLE` or other connection state that is important.

settings.name: after_run_sql
settings.description: Raw SQL statement(s) to execute as soon as the connection to Postgres is opened by the target. Useful for setup like `SET ROLE` or other connection state that is important.

settings.name: host
settings.description: PostgreSQL host
settings.label: Host

settings.name: port
settings.description: PostgreSQL port
settings.label: Port

settings.name: user
settings.description: PostgreSQL user
settings.label: User

settings.name: password
settings.description: PostgreSQL password
settings.label: Password

settings.name: dbname
settings.description: PostgreSQL database name
settings.label: Dbname

settings.name: default_target_schema
settings.description: Name of the schema where the tables will be created. If `schema_mapping` is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is loaded into this schema.
settings.label: Default Target Schema

settings.name: batch_size_rows
settings.description: Maximum number of rows in each batch. At the end of each batch, the rows in the batch are loaded into Postgres.
settings.label: Batch Size Rows

settings.name: flush_all_streams
settings.description: Flush and load every stream into Postgres when one batch is full. Warning: This may trigger the COPY command to use files with low number of records.
settings.label: Flush All Streams

settings.name: parallelism
settings.description: The number of threads used to flush tables. 0 will create a thread for each stream, up to parallelism_max. -1 will create a thread for each CPU core. Any other positive number will create that number of threads, up to parallelism_max.
settings.label: Parallelism

settings.name: parallelism_max
settings.description: Max number of parallel threads to use when flushing tables.
settings.label: Parallelism Max

settings.name: default_target_schema_select_permission
settings.description: Grant USAGE privilege on newly created schemas and grant SELECT privilege on newly created tables to a specific role or a list of roles. If `schema_mapping` is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is granted accordingly.
settings.label: Default Target Schema Select Permission

settings.name: schema_mapping
settings.description: Useful if you want to load multiple streams from one tap to multiple Postgres schemas. If the tap sends the `stream_id` in `<schema_name>-<table_name>` format then this option overwrites the `default_target_schema` value. Note, that using `schema_mapping` you can overwrite the `default_target_schema_select_permission` value to grant SELECT permissions to different groups per schemas or optionally you can create indices automatically for the replicated tables.
settings.label: Schema Mapping

settings.name: add_metadata_columns
settings.description: Metadata columns add extra row level information about data ingestions, (i.e. when was the row read in source, when was inserted or deleted in postgres etc.) Metadata columns are creating automatically by adding extra columns to the tables with a column prefix `_SDC_`. The column names are following the stitch naming conventions documented at https://www.stitchdata.com/docs/data-structure/integration-schemas#sdc-columns. Enabling metadata columns will flag the deleted rows by setting the `_SDC_DELETED_AT` metadata column. Without the `add_metadata_columns` option the deleted rows from singer taps will not be recongisable in Postgres.
settings.label: Add Metadata Columns

settings.name: hard_delete
settings.description: When `hard_delete` option is true then DELETE SQL commands will be performed in Postgres to delete rows in tables. It's achieved by continuously checking the `_SDC_DELETED_AT` metadata column sent by the singer tap. Due to deleting rows requires metadata columns, `hard_delete` option automatically enables the `add_metadata_columns` option as well.
settings.label: Hard Delete

settings.name: data_flattening_max_level
settings.description: Object type RECORD items from taps can be transformed to flattened columns by creating columns automatically. When value is 0 (default) then flattening functionality is turned off.
settings.label: Data Flattening Max Level

settings.name: primary_key_required
settings.description: Log based and Incremental replications on tables with no Primary Key cause duplicates when merging UPDATE events. When set to true, stop loading data if no Primary Key is defined.
settings.label: Primary Key Required

settings.name: validate_records
settings.description: Validate every single record message to the corresponding JSON schema. This option is disabled by default and invalid RECORD messages will fail only at load time by Postgres. Enabling this option will detect invalid records earlier but could cause performance degradation.
settings.label: Validate Records

settings.name: temp_dir
settings.description: (Default: platform-dependent) Directory of temporary CSV files with RECORD messages.
settings.label: Temp Dir

settings.name: url
settings.label: URL
settings.description: Lets you set `user`, `password`, `host`, `port`, and `dbname` in one go using a `postgresql://` URI. Takes precedence over the other settings when set.

settings.name: host
settings.description: Redshift host

settings.name: port
settings.description: Redshift port

settings.name: dbname
settings.label: Database Name
settings.description: Redshift database name

settings.name: user
settings.label: User name
settings.description: Redshift user name

settings.name: password
settings.description: Redshift password

settings.name: s3_bucket
settings.label: S3 Bucket name
settings.description: AWS S3 bucket name

settings.name: default_target_schema
settings.description: Name of the schema where the tables will be created. If schema_mapping is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is loaded into this schema.

settings.name: aws_profile
settings.label: AWS profile name
settings.description: AWS profile name for profile based authentication. If not provided, AWS_PROFILE environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_access_key_id
settings.label: AWS S3 Access Key ID
settings.description: S3 Access Key Id. Used for S3 and Redshift copy operations. If not provided, AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_secret_access_key
settings.label: AWS S3 Secret Access Key
settings.description: S3 Secret Access Key. Used for S3 and Redshift copy operations. If not provided, AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_session_token
settings.label: AWS S3 Session Token
settings.description: S3 AWS STS token for temporary credentials. If not provided, AWS_SESSION_TOKEN environment variable will be used.

settings.name: aws_redshift_copy_role_arn
settings.label: AWS Redshift COPY role ARN
settings.description: AWS Role ARN to be used for the Redshift COPY operation. Used instead of the given AWS keys for the COPY operation if provided - the keys are still used for other S3 operations

settings.name: s3_acl
settings.label: AWS S3 ACL
settings.description: S3 Object ACL

settings.name: s3_key_prefix
settings.label: S3 Key Prefix
settings.description: A static prefix before the generated S3 key names. Using prefixes you can upload files into specific directories in the S3 bucket. Default(None)

settings.name: copy_options
settings.label: COPY options
settings.value: EMPTYASNULL BLANKSASNULL TRIMBLANKS TRUNCATECOLUMNS TIMEFORMAT 'auto' COMPUPDATE OFF STATUPDATE OFF
settings.description: Parameters to use in the COPY command when loading data to Redshift. Some basic file formatting parameters are fixed values and not recommended overriding them by custom values. They are like: `CSV GZIP DELIMITER ',' REMOVEQUOTES ESCAPE`.

settings.name: batch_size_rows
settings.description: Maximum number of rows in each batch. At the end of each batch, the rows in the batch are loaded into Redshift.

settings.name: flush_all_streams
settings.description: Flush and load every stream into Redshift when one batch is full. Warning - This may trigger the COPY command to use files with low number of records, and may cause performance problems.

settings.name: parallelism
settings.description: The number of threads used to flush tables. 0 will create a thread for each stream, up to parallelism_max. -1 will create a thread for each CPU core. Any other positive number will create that number of threads, up to parallelism_max.

settings.name: max_parallelism
settings.description: Max number of parallel threads to use when flushing tables.

settings.name: default_target_schema_select_permissions
settings.description: Grant USAGE privilege on newly created schemas and grant SELECT privilege on newly created tables to a specific list of users or groups. If schema_mapping is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is granted accordingly.

settings.name: schema_mapping
settings.description: Useful if you want to load multiple streams from one tap to multiple Redshift schemas. If the tap sends the stream_id in <schema_name>-<table_name> format then this option overwrites the default_target_schema value. Note, that using schema_mapping you can overwrite the default_target_schema_select_permissions value to grant SELECT permissions to different groups per schemas or optionally you can create indices automatically for the replicated tables.

settings.name: disable_table_cache
settings.description: By default the connector caches the available table structures in Redshift at startup. In this way it doesn't need to run additional queries when ingesting data to check if altering the target tables is required. With disable_table_cache option you can turn off this caching. You will always see the most recent table structures but will cause an extra query runtime.

settings.name: add_metadata_columns
settings.description: Metadata columns add extra row level information about data ingestions, (i.e. when was the row read in source, when was inserted or deleted in redshift etc.) Metadata columns are creating automatically by adding extra columns to the tables with a column prefix _SDC_. The metadata columns are documented at https://transferwise.github.io/pipelinewise/data_structure/sdc-columns.html. Enabling metadata columns will flag the deleted rows by setting the _SDC_DELETED_AT metadata column. Without the add_metadata_columns option the deleted rows from singer taps will not be recongisable in Redshift.

settings.name: hard_delete
settings.description: When hard_delete option is true then DELETE SQL commands will be performed in Redshift to delete rows in tables. It's achieved by continuously checking the _SDC_DELETED_AT metadata column sent by the singer tap. Due to deleting rows requires metadata columns, hard_delete option automatically enables the add_metadata_columns option as well.

settings.name: data_flattening_max_level
settings.description: Object type RECORD items from taps can be loaded into VARIANT columns as JSON (default) or we can flatten the schema by creating columns automatically. When value is 0 (default) then flattening functionality is turned off.

settings.name: primary_key_required
settings.description: Log based and Incremental replications on tables with no Primary Key cause duplicates when merging UPDATE events. When set to true, stop loading data if no Primary Key is defined.

settings.name: validate_records
settings.description: Validate every single record message to the corresponding JSON schema. This option is disabled by default and invalid RECORD messages will fail only at load time by Redshift. Enabling this option will detect invalid records earlier but could cause performance degradation.

settings.name: skip_updates
settings.description: Do not update existing records when Primary Key is defined. Useful to improve performance when records are immutable, e.g. events

settings.name: compression
settings.description: The compression method to use when writing files to S3 and running Redshift COPY.

settings.name: slices
settings.description: The number of slices to split files into prior to running COPY on Redshift. This should be set to the number of Redshift slices. The number of slices per node depends on the node size of the cluster - run SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT slice) slices FROM stv_slices to calculate this. Defaults to 1.

settings.name: temp_dir
settings.label: Temp directory
settings.description: (Default: platform-dependent) Directory of temporary CSV files with RECORD messages.

variants.name: datamill-co
dependencies: `target-snowflake` [requires](https://www.psycopg.org/docs/install.html#runtime-requirements) the [`libpq` library](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/libpq.html) to be available on your system. If you've installed PostgreSQL, you should already have it, but you can also install it by itself using the [`libpq-dev` package](https://pkgs.org/download/libpq-dev) on Ubuntu/Debian or the [`libpq` Homebrew formula](https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/libpq) on macOS.

settings.name: snowflake_account
settings.description: `ACCOUNT` might require the `region` and `cloud` platform where your account is located, in the form of: `<your_account_name>.<region_id>.<cloud>` (e.g. `xy12345.east-us-2.azure`) Refer to Snowflake's documentation about Account: https://docs.snowflake.net/manuals/user-guide/connecting.html#your-snowflake-account-name-and-url

settings.name: snowflake_role
settings.description: If not specified, Snowflake will use the user's default role.

settings.name: snowflake_authenticator
settings.description: Specifies the authentication provider for snowflake to use. Valud options are the internal one ("snowflake"), a browser session ("externalbrowser"), or Okta ("https://<your_okta_account_name>.okta.com"). See the snowflake docs for more details.

settings.name: invalid_records_detect
settings.description: Include `false` in your config to disable crashing on invalid records

settings.name: invalid_records_threshold
settings.description: Include a positive value `n` in your config to allow at most `n` invalid records per stream before giving up.

settings.name: disable_collection
settings.description: Include `true` in your config to disable Singer Usage Logging: https://github.com/datamill-co/target-snowflake#usage-logging

settings.name: logging_level
settings.description: The level for logging. Set to `DEBUG` to get things like queries executed, timing of those queries, etc.

settings.name: persist_empty_tables
settings.description: Whether the Target should create tables which have no records present in Remote.

settings.name: state_support
settings.description: Whether the Target should emit `STATE` messages to stdout for further consumption. In this mode, which is on by default, STATE messages are buffered in memory until all the records that occurred before them are flushed according to the batch flushing schedule the target is configured with.

settings.name: target_s3.bucket
settings.description: When included, use S3 to stage files. Bucket where staging files should be uploaded to.

settings.name: target_s3.key_prefix
settings.description: Prefix for staging file uploads to allow for better delineation of tmp files

settings.name: account
settings.description: Snowflake account name (i.e. rtXXXXX.eu-central-1)

settings.name: dbname
settings.description: Snowflake Database name

settings.name: user
settings.description: Snowflake User

settings.name: password
settings.description: Snowflake Password

settings.name: warehouse
settings.description: Snowflake virtual warehouse name

settings.name: s3_bucket
settings.description: S3 Bucket name

settings.name: stage
settings.description: Named external stage name created at pre-requirements section. Has to be a fully qualified name including the schema name

settings.name: file_format
settings.description: Named file format name created at pre-requirements section. Has to be a fully qualified name including the schema name.

settings.name: default_target_schema
settings.description: Name of the schema where the tables will be created, without database prefix. If `schema_mapping` is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is loaded into this schema.

settings.name: aws_access_key_id
settings.description: S3 Access Key Id. If not provided, `AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID` environment variable or IAM role will be used

settings.name: aws_secret_access_key
settings.description: S3 Secret Access Key. If not provided, `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY` environment variable or IAM role will be used

settings.name: aws_session_token
settings.description: AWS Session token. If not provided, `AWS_SESSION_TOKEN` environment variable will be used

settings.name: aws_profile
settings.description: AWS profile name for profile based authentication. If not provided, `AWS_PROFILE` environment variable will be used.

settings.name: s3_key_prefix
settings.description: A static prefix before the generated S3 key names. Using prefixes you can upload files into specific directories in the S3 bucket.

settings.name: s3_endpoint_url
settings.description: The complete URL to use for the constructed client. This is allowing to use non-native s3 account.

settings.name: s3_region_name
settings.description: Default region when creating new connections

settings.name: s3_acl
settings.description: S3 ACL name to set on the uploaded files

settings.name: batch_size_rows
settings.description: Maximum number of rows in each batch. At the end of each batch, the rows in the batch are loaded into Snowflake.

settings.name: flush_all_streams
settings.description: Flush and load every stream into Snowflake when one batch is full. Warning: This may trigger the COPY command to use files with low number of records, and may cause performance problems.

settings.name: parallelism
settings.description: The number of threads used to flush tables. 0 will create a thread for each stream, up to parallelism_max. -1 will create a thread for each CPU core. Any other positive number will create that number of threads, up to parallelism_max.

settings.name: parallelism_max
settings.description: Max number of parallel threads to use when flushing tables.

settings.name: default_target_schema_select_permission
settings.description: Grant USAGE privilege on newly created schemas and grant SELECT privilege on newly created tables to a specific role or a list of roles. If `schema_mapping` is not defined then every stream sent by the tap is granted accordingly.

settings.name: schema_mapping
settings.description: Useful if you want to load multiple streams from one tap to multiple Snowflake schemas. If the tap sends the `stream_id` in `<schema_name>-<table_name>` format then this option overwrites the `default_target_schema` value. Note, that using `schema_mapping` you can overwrite the `default_target_schema_select_permission` value to grant SELECT permissions to different groups per schemas or optionally you can create indices automatically for the replicated tables.

settings.name: disable_table_cache
settings.description: By default the connector caches the available table structures in Snowflake at startup. In this way it doesn't need to run additional queries when ingesting data to check if altering the target tables is required. With `disable_table_cache` option you can turn off this caching. You will always see the most recent table structures but will cause an extra query runtime.

settings.name: client_side_encryption_master_key
settings.description: When this is defined, Client-Side Encryption is enabled. The data in S3 will be encrypted, No third parties, including Amazon AWS and any ISPs, can see data in the clear. Snowflake COPY command will decrypt the data once it's in Snowflake. The master key must be 256-bit length and must be encoded as base64 string.

settings.name: client_side_encryption_stage_object
settings.description: Required when `client_side_encryption_master_key` is defined. The name of the encrypted stage object in Snowflake that created separately and using the same encryption master key.

settings.name: add_metadata_columns
settings.description: Metadata columns add extra row level information about data ingestions, (i.e. when was the row read in source, when was inserted or deleted in snowflake etc.) Metadata columns are creating automatically by adding extra columns to the tables with a column prefix `_SDC_`. The column names are following the stitch naming conventions documented at https://www.stitchdata.com/docs/data-structure/integration-schemas#sdc-columns. Enabling metadata columns will flag the deleted rows by setting the `_SDC_DELETED_AT` metadata column. Without the `add_metadata_columns` option the deleted rows from singer taps will not be recongisable in Snowflake.

settings.name: hard_delete
settings.description: When `hard_delete` option is true then DELETE SQL commands will be performed in Snowflake to delete rows in tables. It's achieved by continuously checking the `_SDC_DELETED_AT` metadata column sent by the singer tap. Due to deleting rows requires metadata columns, `hard_delete` option automatically enables the `add_metadata_columns` option as well.

settings.name: data_flattening_max_level
settings.description: Object type RECORD items from taps can be loaded into VARIANT columns as JSON (default) or we can flatten the schema by creating columns automatically. When value is 0 (default) then flattening functionality is turned off.

settings.name: primary_key_required
settings.description: Log based and Incremental replications on tables with no Primary Key cause duplicates when merging UPDATE events. When set to true, stop loading data if no Primary Key is defined.

settings.name: validate_records
settings.description: Validate every single record message to the corresponding JSON schema. This option is disabled by default and invalid RECORD messages will fail only at load time by Snowflake. Enabling this option will detect invalid records earlier but could cause performance degradation.

settings.name: temp_dir
settings.description: (Default: platform-dependent) Directory of temporary CSV files with RECORD messages.

settings.name: no_compression
settings.description: Generate uncompressed CSV files when loading to Snowflake. Normally, by default GZIP compressed files are generated.

settings.name: query_tag
settings.description: Optional string to tag executed queries in Snowflake. Replaces tokens `schema` and `table` with the appropriate values. The tags are displayed in the output of the Snowflake `QUERY_HISTORY`, `QUERY_HISTORY_BY_*` functions.

settings.name: account
settings.description: Account Name in Snowflake (https://<account_name>.snowflakecomputing.com)

settings.name: username
settings.description: The username you use for logging in

settings.name: password
settings.description: The password you use for logging in

settings.name: role
settings.description: Role to be used for loading the data, e.g. `LOADER`. Also this role is GRANTed usage to all tables and schemas created

settings.name: database
settings.description: The name of the Snowflake database you want to use

settings.name: warehouse
settings.description: The name of the Snowflake warehouse you want to use

settings.name: batch_size
settings.description: How many records are sent to Snowflake at a time?

settings.name: timestamp_column
settings.description: Name of the column used for recording the timestamp when Data are uploaded to Snowflake.

settings.name: database
settings.label: Database Name
settings.description: Name of the SQLite database file to be used or created, relative to the project root. The `.db` extension is optional and will be added automatically when omitted.

settings.name: batch_size
settings.label: Batch Size
settings.description: How many records are sent to SQLite at a time?

settings.name: timestamp_column
settings.label: Timestamp Column
settings.description: Name of the column used for recording the timestamp when Data are loaded to SQLite.

settings.name: database
settings.label: Database Name
settings.description: Name of the SQLite database file to be used or created, relative to the project root. The `.db` extension is optional and will be added automatically when omitted.

settings.name: batch_size
settings.description: How many records are sent to SQLite at a time?

settings.name: timestamp_column
settings.description: Name of the column used for recording the timestamp when Data are loaded to SQLite.

settings.name: file_naming_scheme
settings.label: File Naming Scheme
settings.description: The scheme with which output files will be named. Naming scheme may leverage any of the following substitutions - \n\n- `{stream_name}`- `{datestamp}`- `{timestamp}`

settings.name: datestamp_format
settings.label: Datestamp Format
settings.description: A python format string to use when outputting the `{datestamp}` string. For reference, see - https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#strftime-and-strptime-format-codes

settings.name: timestamp_format
settings.label: Timestamp Format
settings.description: A python format string to use when outputting the `{datestamp}` string. For reference, see - https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#strftime-and-strptime-format-codes

settings.name: timestamp_timezone
settings.label: Timestamp Timezone
settings.description: The timezone code or name to use when generating `{timestamp}` and `{datestamp}`. Defaults to "UTC". For a list of possible values, please see - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_tz_database_time_zones

settings.name: stream_maps
settings.label: Stream Maps
settings.description: Allows inline stream transformations and aliasing. For more information see - https://sdk.meltano.com/en/latest/stream_maps.html

settings.name: record_insert_jsonpath
settings.label: Record Insert Jsonpath
settings.description:
A jsonpath string determining the insertion point for new records. Currently, this must be the path to a map key which will be populated by a list of records. 

For example "$.metrics" will populate the file with `metrics - [{<record1>},{<record2>},...]` 

For JSONPath syntax help, see - https://jsonpath.com

settings.name: record_key_property_name
settings.label: Record Key Property Name
settings.description: A property in the record which will be used as the dictionary key.\n\nIf this property is provided, records will be written as key-value objects; if omitted, records are written as a list.

settings.name: record_sort_property_name
settings.label: Record Sort Property Name
settings.description: A property in the record which will be used as a sort key.\n\nIf this property is omitted, records will not be sorted.

settings.name: overwrite_behavior
settings.label: Overwrite Behavior
settings.description:
Determines the overwrite behavior if destination file already exists. Must be one of the following string values - 

- `append_records` (default) - append records at the insertion point
- `replace_records` - replace all records at the insertion point
- `replace_file` - replace entire file using `default_yaml_template`

settings.name: default_yaml_template
settings.label: Default Yaml Template
settings.description: Text string to use for a yaml template file. This text will be used to create a new file if the destination file does not exist.
